title: 105_s1790
content: The "Social Security Preservation Act of 1997" is the short title of this Act. It involves the investment of the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. The Social Security Act is amended to allow investments in marketable interest-bearing obligations of the United States or obligations guaranteed by the United States. The Managing Trustee determines annual surplus for each Trust Fund to be invested in the following fiscal year. The Social Security Act is amended to allow investments in marketable interest-bearing obligations of the United States or obligations guaranteed by the United States. The annual surplus for each Trust Fund is determined by the Managing Trustee and can be invested in certificates of deposit in insured depository institutions. The Social Security Act is amended to allow investments in marketable interest-bearing obligations of the United States or obligations guaranteed by the United States. The amendments made by this section shall apply with respect to annual surpluses as of the end of fiscal years beginning on or after October 1, 2002. Protection of the Social Security Trust Funds from the public debt limit is ensured by allowing investments in marketable interest-bearing obligations of the United States or obligations guaranteed by the United States. This amendment applies to annual surpluses as of the end of fiscal years starting on or after October 1, 2002. Protection of Trust Funds: No officer or employee of the United States may delay deposits or credits to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund or the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund to avoid increasing public debt obligations. Additionally, disinvestment from these Trust Funds is prohibited. Protection of Trust Funds: Disinvestment from Trust Funds invested in public debt obligations is prohibited unless it is to pay benefits or administrative expenses during a period when further public debt obligations cannot be issued. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue public debt obligations to obtain cash for payment of benefits or expenses from Trust Funds, regardless of the public debt limit, with advance notice required before disinvestment from Trust Funds. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress and the Comptroller General prior to undertaking a sale or redemption of public debt obligations. The Comptroller General will review compliance and issue findings and recommendations. The term "public debt obligation" refers to any obligation subject to the public debt limit.
